caption_original:
SCAM ALERT: Beware of scammers impersonating the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA). 

These scammers “spoof” phone numbers to make it look like the call is from the CRA claiming that you owe the government back taxes. These scammers threaten arrest if you don't make an immediate payment through untraceable money transfers and prepaid credit cards.  

Always be vigilant when disclosing personal and financial information. Here are some ways to tell if it's really the CRA: http://ow.ly/YExnK

#DYK being married or having a common-law partner can affect the amount of federal tax you pay on both your income and investments?

TIP: To maximize your tax credits, the person with the lower income should claim all of the couple's medical expenses on his or her tax return. This is because the federal government offers a non-refundable tax credit for expenses that are above a percentage (3% in 2015) of one partner's net income. Get more tax tips here: http://ow.ly/YnMeQ

Do you qualify for the working income tax benefit (WITB)? 

The WITB is a refundable tax credit which provides tax relief for eligible, low-income individuals and families who are in the workforce. To qualify, you must be 19 years old or older by December 31st and be a resident of Canada. Find out more: http://ow.ly/YEyTW

Need to make a purchase today but don't have the cash until next week? 

#DYK you know that credit cards offer a 21-day interest-free grace period? That means that as long as you pay off your statement in full by the due date, you won't be charged any interest. Think of it as an interest free loan!

As with most things, however, there are some exceptions. For example, the grace period doesn't apply to cash advances. Find out more here: http://ow.ly/YEybW

DYK one of the most common mistakes post-secondary students make when filing a tax return is having the wrong address on file with the Canada Revenue Agency? It could be a sign of identity theft. Make sure to review your statements as soon as they come in and report any errors to your financial institution immediately. And notify them if you haven't been receiving your statements.

caption_original: #DYK your financial institution can charge you for services like holding post-dated cheques or cancelling e-transfers? Make sure you know where your money is going: ask your financial institution about the costs associated with the services you use. http://ow.ly/Yxwyk

caption_original:
Should you care about your credit score? 

Short answer: yes. Long answer: yes.  

Your credit report is a history of how you have met your financial obligations. The higher your score, the more likely you are to be approved for loans, credit cards and lower interest rates. A low credit score could lead to problems when trying to rent an apartment or even prevent you from getting a job you want! 

Get more details on why your credit score matters and how to find out yours: http://ow.ly/YED5R

Are you a savvy online shopper? 

Savvy online shoppers make it a habit to check for a privacy policy before buying online. For many online vendors, your personal information is as important as your money. Make sure they detail why they are asking for your info and how they intend to use it. If it doesn’t sound reasonable, then do yourself a solid and take your business elsewhere. http://ow.ly/XNCoW

Planning a move? Choosing the right moving company can make all the difference!

Before hiring a company, do your research. Get quotes from at least three reliable movers in your area so you can compare options and costs. Scam operators lure customers in with cut-rate prices and grandiose promises. Then they inflate the price on moving day, holding your stuff for ransom. 

Check out the Canadian Association of Movers’ directory of reputable movers to get started: http://ow.ly/YlmEN

#BuyerBeware: Sales between individuals (aka. private sales) are usually not covered by consumer legislation.  

That means if something goes wrong with your private sale, it’s unlikely that your local consumer affairs office can get involved. So it’s up to you to do your homework; otherwise, if you didn’t get what you paid for, you may be looking at more money spent on court action. #ouch http://ow.ly/YgNz9
